verses.text: King Belshazzar threw a great feast for a thousand of his nobles, and he drank wine before them.
verses.comment: Belshazzar is introduced as a powerful ruler, setting the stage for an event highlighting the limits of earthly authority. See also parallels to royal feasts in Esther 1:3.

verses.text: As Belshazzar was tasting the wine, he commanded that the gold and silver vessels which his father Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the temple in Jerusalem be brought in, so that the king and his nobles, his wives, and his concubines could drink from them.
verses.comment: The sacred vessels from the Jerusalem temple were desecrated for pagan use, a grave offense. This highlights the continued reverence for holy objects and worship handed down through generations.

verses.text: So they brought the gold vessels taken from the temple, the house of God in Jerusalem; and the king and his nobles, his wives, and his concubines drank from them.
verses.comment: The repetition confirms the sacrilege. It points to the idea that the true worship of God entails respect for what is dedicated to Him.

verses.text: They drank wine and praised the gods of gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, and stone.
verses.comment: Drinking from holy vessels while worshipping false gods shows the depth of idolatry and contrasts true worship with human inventions.

verses.text: Suddenly, fingers of a human hand appeared and wrote on the plaster of the wall of the king’s palace, opposite the lampstand. The king saw the hand as it wrote.
verses.comment: A direct supernatural intervention. The lampstand detail echoes the temple’s menorah, linking this event to Israelite worship traditions.

verses.text: His face turned pale, and his thoughts alarmed him; the joints of his hips loosened and his knees knocked together.
verses.comment: The king’s terror illustrates the futility of earthly majesty when confronted by divine judgment.

verses.text: The king cried loudly to summon the enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers. He said to the wise men of Babylon, 'Whoever reads this writing and explains its meaning to me will be clothed in purple, have a gold chain placed around his neck, and be made the third highest ruler in the kingdom.'
verses.comment: The offer of royal honors and authority mirrors later symbolic vestments of office and leadership—see the color purple as a sign of royalty in both Testaments.

verses.text: But all the king’s wise men came in, and they could not read the writing or make known its meaning to the king.
verses.comment: Once again, human wisdom fails where only divine revelation can interpret the mysteries of God.

verses.text: Then King Belshazzar was greatly alarmed, and his face grew even paler. His nobles were bewildered.
verses.comment: The public confusion further emphasizes the futility of secular solutions to spiritual problems.

verses.text: When the queen heard the voices of the king and his nobles, she came to the banquet hall. She said, 'O king, live forever! Do not let your thoughts trouble you or your face grow pale.'
verses.comment: The queen’s entrance and counsel provide background for divine wisdom entering the midst of confusion.

verses.text: 'There is a man in your kingdom in whom is a spirit of the holy gods. In the days of your father, light, understanding, and wisdom like that of the gods were found in him; and King Nebuchadnezzar appointed him chief of the magicians, enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers.'
verses.comment: Daniel’s spiritual gifts surpass worldly magic. This points toward the greater gifts of the Spirit found in God’s holy people.

verses.text: 'This Daniel, whom the king named Belteshazzar, was found to have an extraordinary spirit, knowledge, and understanding, able to interpret dreams, solve riddles, and explain mysteries. Call for Daniel, and he will give you the interpretation.'
verses.comment: Daniel’s God-given abilities prefigure later spiritual gifts, showing the continuity of God’s plan through chosen vessels.

verses.text: Then Daniel was brought before the king. The king spoke and said to Daniel, 'Are you Daniel, one of the exiles from Judah, whom my father the king brought from Judah?'
verses.comment: Daniel's identity as an exile underscores the theme of God working through those set apart and called, foreshadowing the chosen people.

verses.text: 'I have heard of you, that the spirit of the gods is in you, and that light, understanding, and excellent wisdom are found in you.'
verses.comment: God’s Spirit bestows wisdom and comprehension, contrasting merely human claims to insight. Revelation comes through those marked by the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: Now the wise men and enchanters have been brought before me to read this writing and explain it, but they could not show the interpretation of the message.
verses.comment: Worldly wisdom proves insufficient, just as the wisdom of God confounds philosophers and rulers (see 1 Cor. 1:20).

verses.text: 'But I have heard that you can give interpretations and solve mysteries. Now, if you can read the writing and explain its meaning, you shall be clothed in purple, have a gold chain around your neck, and be made the third highest ruler in the kingdom.'
verses.comment: Daniel is offered temporal honors, yet his fidelity to God remains foremost, illustrating the call to holiness above earthly praise.

verses.text: Then Daniel answered and said before the king, 'You may keep your gifts for yourself or give your rewards to someone else; but nevertheless I will read the writing for the king and explain its meaning to him.'
verses.comment: Daniel rejects material reward for spiritual service, a trait later modeled by Jesus and the apostles.

verses.text: 'O king, the Most High God gave Nebuchadnezzar your father kingship, greatness, glory, and majesty.'
verses.comment: True authority comes from God alone, reinforcing divine right and sovereignty.

verses.text: 'Because of the greatness he gave him, all peoples, nations, and languages trembled and feared before him. He killed whom he wished and spared whom he wished; whom he wished he raised up, and whom he wished he put down.'
verses.comment: Shows the breadth of civil authority, suggesting God's mysterious allowance for earthly powers within Providence.

verses.text: 'But when his heart was lifted up and his spirit hardened by pride, he was deposed from his royal throne, and his glory was taken from him.'
verses.comment: Pride led to Nebuchadnezzar’s downfall, a recurring biblical warning against self-exaltation.

verses.text: 'He was driven from mankind, his mind became like that of an animal; he lived with the wild donkeys, was fed grass like an ox, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, until he realized that the Most High God rules the kingdom of men and sets over it whomever He wishes.'
verses.comment: Humiliation led to true recognition of God’s sovereignty, suggesting repentance and conversion as transformative experiences.

verses.text: 'But you, his son Belshazzar, have not humbled your heart, though you knew all this.'
verses.comment: Belshazzar failed despite clear witness. The call to humility is continual (see James 4:10).

verses.text: 'But you have lifted yourself up against the Lord of heaven. You and your nobles have brought the vessels of His house before you, and you and your nobles, wives, and concubines drank wine from them. You praised the gods of silver and gold, bronze, iron, wood, and stone, which do not see or hear or know. But you have not honored the God in whose hand your breath and all your ways belong.'
verses.comment: This condemnation alludes to the deep offense of sacrilege and idolatry. God's sustaining power over life is emphasized.

verses.text: Therefore He sent the hand that wrote this inscription.
verses.comment: God’s direct intervention displays His active governance over the affairs of men.

verses.text: 'This is the inscription that was written: MENE, MENE, TEKEL, PARSIN.'
verses.comment: The Aramaic words are untranslated in many versions; here they are shown as directly written on the wall.

verses.text: 'This is the interpretation of the message: MENE—God has numbered your kingdom and finished it.'
verses.comment: MENE means ‘numbered’; Daniel reveals the divine judgment in prophetic fulfillment.

verses.text: 'TEKEL—you have been weighed on the scales and found wanting.'
verses.comment: Judgment imagery of scales echoes numerous scriptural themes of justice and examination.

verses.text: 'PERES—your kingdom has been divided and given to the Medes and Persians.'
verses.comment: PERES (related to PARSIN) means ‘divided’—critical fulfillment demonstrating the ultimate sovereignty of God over kingdoms.

verses.text: Then Belshazzar commanded, and they clothed Daniel in purple, placed a gold chain around his neck, and proclaimed him the third highest ruler in the kingdom.
verses.comment: Daniel receives honors in Babylon, yet his ultimate reward, like all saints, comes from faithfulness to God—not earthly position.

verses.text: That very night Belshazzar the Chaldean king was killed.
verses.comment: Immediate fulfillment of prophecy—God’s justice is swift and certain.

verses.text: And Darius the Mede received the kingdom, being about sixty-two years old.
verses.comment: The Medo-Persian empire begins, as prophesied. The transfer of kingdoms shows God’s control in historical events, foreshadowing a future universal reign and enduring continuity among leaders appointed by God.
